message_1: How many ways can you divide a set of 6 items into non-empty subsets if their order within the subsets does not matter?
message_2:
To divide a set of 6 items into non-empty subsets, we can use the Bell number. The Bell number B(n) counts the number of ways to partition a set of n elements into non-empty subsets. 

For n = 6, the Bell number B(6) = 203.

So, there are 203 ways to divide a set of 6 items into non-empty subsets if their order within the subsets does not matter.
